Description: Circular white and grey glazed composition tile in the form of a rosette. The roundel is coloured grey and is flush with the eight white petals, with a small applied yellow boss in the centre. The back of the tile is smooth.
Curator's comments: Tile inlays often featured in New Kingdom palaces and temples, on the door frames, columns, cavetto cornices, and throne pedestals, set into recesses in the stone and mud brick (Arnold 2003, 20-1). This tile was found in the remains of the palace of Ramses III at Tell el-Yahudiya, along with other decorative tiles featuring cartouches of Ramesses III, foreign captives, rekhyt-birds on neb-baskets, and floral friezes of lotus flowers and grapes. William Flinders Petrie’s excavations at Tell el Yahudiya uncovered additions to the town made by Ramses III, including a thick mud brick enclosure wall and a palace. The remains of the palace included a large red granite column base, calcite pavement blocks, and remnants of glazed tiles, as well as calcite decorative inlays featuring the cartouche of Ramses III and fragments depicting human and leonine elements (Petrie 1906, 8, 17, pl. 16A). Gaston Maspero commented on the palace at Tell el-Yahudiya: ‘The core of the building is in limestone and alabaster; but instead of the usual sculpted panels, there is a sort of mosaic, made up in almost equal parts of cut stone and painted clay. The most commonly used feature is a roundel in friable fireclay coated with blue or gray glaze, against which simple rose forms, geometric frameworks, spider’s webs or open flowers are picked out in shades of cream. The central core is in relief, with leaves and designs pressed into the mass of the clay. These roundels vary in diameter from one to ten centimetres, and were attached to the walls using a very fine cement’ (Maspero 1887, 257-8; Ziegler 2002, no. 119, p. 436). The tiles were probably produced by moulding the roundel on both sides using pure, uncoloured sand-quartz siliceous paste, and then coloured paste added to the hollowed out area between the petals. Finally, a yellow boss would have been applied to the surface. There are 160 rosette tiles from Tell el-Yahudiya in the British Museum collection and another 56 are in the collection of the Louvre (Ziegler 2002, no. 119, p. 436). Bibliography: PM IV (Oxford, 1934), p. 57; D. Arnold, ‘The encyclopaedia of ancient Egyptian architecture’ (London, I. B. Tauris, 2003), pp. 20-1; British Museum, ‘A guide to the fourth, fifth and sixth Egyptian rooms, and the Coptic room’ (London, British Museum, 1922), pp. 146-7; F.D. Friedman, ‘Gifts of the Nile: Ancient Egyptian Faience’ (London, Thames and Hudson, 1998), nos. 51, 54-6; W.C. Hayes, ‘Glazed Tiles from a Palace of Ramesses II at Kantir’, (New York, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1937); G. Maspero, ‘L’Archaéologie Égyptienne’, (Paris, Quantin, 1887), pp. 257-8, figs. 231-2; W.F. Petrie and J.G. Duncan, ‘Hyksos and Israelite cities, Double Volume’ (London, School of Archaeology, University College and B. Quaritch, 1906), pp. 8, 17, pl. 16A; C. Ziegler, ‘The Pharaohs’, (Milan: Bompiani, 2002), no. 119, p. 436.
